File.Title: Localization of Cholinergic Neurons in the Forebrain and Brainstem That Project to the Suprachiasmatic Nucleus of the Hypothalamus in Rat
File.Authors: KESHAVAN G. BINA, BENJAMIN RUSAK, AND KAZUE SEMBA

Abstract.S: In mammals, the suprachiasmatic nucleus is responsible for the generation of most circadian rhythms and their entrainment to environmental cues.
Cholinergic agents can alter circadian rhythm phase, and fibres immunoreactive for choline acetyltransferase, the biosynthetic enzyme for acetylcholine, are present in the suprachiasmatic nucleus.
Since there are no cholinergic somata in the suprachiasmatic nucleus, these fibres must represent the terminals of cholinergic neurons whose cell bodies are located elsewhere in the brain.

This study was aimed at locating the cholinergic neurons that project to the suprachiasmatic nucleus by retrograde and anterograde tract-tracing and immunohistochemistry for choline acetyltransferase in the rat.

After injection of fluorogold, a retrograde tracer, into the suprachiasmatic nucleus, retrogradely labelled neurons that were immunopositive for choline acetyltransferase were located throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex, with highest densities in the substantia innominata and the nucleus basalis magnocellularis.
A few cells were also located in the medial septum and in the vertical and horizontal limbs of the diagonal band of Broca.
In the brainstem, double-labelled neurons were located in the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus, pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus and the parabigeminal nucleus.
Injections of the anterograde tracer biocytin in these three brainstem nuclei resulted in fibre labelling in the suprachiasmatic nucleus, consistent with the retrograde findings.
No clearly double-labelled cells were located in the retina.

These results suggest that the suprachiasmatic nucleus receives cholinergic afferents from both the basal forebrain and mesopontine tegmentum which may mediate cholinergic effects on circadian rhythms. c 1993 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: Circadian rhythms are endogenously generated rhythms with a period of about 24 hours.
Under natural conditions these circadian rhythms are synchronized to environmental cues such as illumination and temperature cycles.

In mammals, the generation of circadian rhythms in behaviour and physiology and their synchronization to environmental cues are regulated by neural mechanisms centered in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the hypothalamus.
Evidence supporting this role for the SCN comes from a variety of approaches (for reviews see Meijer and Rietveld, '89; Rusak, '89; Hastings et al., '91).

Brief light pulses administered to animals maintained in continuous darkness are capable of shifting the phase of their behavioural and physiological rhythms in a direction which depends on the time of administration of the pulse.
Light exposure in the early subjective night delays, and in the late subjective night advances, the onset of activity rhythms (DeCoursey, '64; Daan and Pittendrigh, '76; Pittendrigh and Daan, '76).
Such phase-dependent responses can be summarized as a phase response curve, plotting the type of phase shift produced against the circadian phase of application.

The phase response curve for intraventricularly administered carbachol, a nonspecific cholinergic agonist, has been shown to mimic partially the pattern of sensitivity to the phase shifting effects of light in rats, mice and hamsters (Zatz and Brownstein, '79; Zatz and Herkenham, '81; Earnest and Turek, '83,'85; Meijer et al., '88; Bina and Rusak, '91), suggesting that acetylcholine (ACh) may play a role in the photic entrainment pathway.

Additional evidence for a cholinergic role comes from evidence that nicotinic receptor antagonists block the phase shifting effects of light on pineal serotonin N-acetyltransferase (Zatz and Brownstein, '81) and locomotor activity (Keefe et al., '87).

Electrophysiological studies have shown that cells in the SCN are responsive to iontophoretically applied ACh, both in vivo and in vitro (Nishino and Koizumi, '77; Kow and Pfaff, '84; Miller et al., '871, implicating the existence of cholinergic receptors within the SCN.
However, evidence against the presence of such receptors exists (for review, see Rusak and Bina, '90).

In brief, the rat SCN itself is not labelled with either 3H-acetylcholine or 3H-nicotine (Segal et al., '78; Clarke et al., '85; van der Zee et al., '911, but a-bungarotoxin binds to sites in a region dorsal and lateral to the SCN (Segal et al., '78; Block and Billiar, '81; Miller et al., '82; Fuchs and Hoppens, '87).

It is known, however, that a-bungarotoxin binds strongly to nicotinic receptors in the peripheral nervous system (Martin et al., '89) but not to those in the central nervous system (Clarke et al., '85).
Fibres containing choline acetyltransferase (CUT), the biosynthetic enzyme for ACh, have been localized in the rat SCN (van den Pol and Tsujimoto, '85; Ichikawa and Hirata, '86).
In the absence of evidence for ChAT in SCN neurons, these fibres can be assumed to derive from sources extrinsic to the SCN.
However, the location of the neurons which contribute these fibres is not known.
The SCN receives a projection from cells in the basal forebrain (Pickard, '821, a region that is known to contain cholinergic neurons.
Therefore, this region appears to be a likely source of the cholinergic projection to the SCN.

Consistent with this possibility, Fuller et al. ('89) reported in an abstract that neurons in the diagonal band of Broca project to the SCN and also contain acetylcholinesterase (AChE), an enzyme involved in the degradation of ACh.
The present study was carried out in rats to clarify the anatomy of cholinergic input to the SCN.

The study involved visualization of fibres and fibre terminals immunopositive for ChAT in the SCN by means of a sensitive immunocytochemical technique (Ojima et al., '88) to confirm the presence of cholinergic fibres in the SCN.

Then a retrograde tracer, fluorogold, was injected into the SCN, in combination with immunohistochemistry for CUT, to identify cholinergic neurons in the forebrain and brainstem (major brain areas containing cholinergic projection neurons) as afferent sources of these fibres.
These projections were further confirmed by injecting an anterograde tracer, biocytin, into the brainstem cholinergic nuclei and visualizing biocytin-labelled fibres and terminals in the SCN.
A preliminary report of this study has been presented (Bina et al., '90a).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Three separate sets of experiments were carried out to identify cholinergic cells which project to the SCN.
The first study used a sensitive immunocytochemical method to visualize fibres and terminals expressing ChAT immunoreactivity in the SCN.

The second study involved retrograde tracing with fluorogold (Fluorochrome, Englewood, CO) as the tracer, injected into the SCN, and evaluation of both forebrain and brainstem cholinergic cell regions as potential sources of the cholinergic projections.
The third set of studies used biocytin (Sigma Chemical Co., St.
Louis, MO) as an anterograde tracer, which was injected into brainstem cholinergic nuclei.

Anterograde studies were not performed for projections from the forebrain because, in comparison to cholinergic neurons in the brainstem, forebrain cholinergic neurons are more diffusely distributed, and very large injections spanning, but also restricted to, the entire rostrocaudal extent of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex would have been very difficult to produce.

In addition, the cholinergic nature of the anterogradely labelled fibres could not be confirmed because although the combination of ChAT immunofluorescence and fluorescence-conjugated avidin for biocytin would be a most suitable method for this purpose, the immunofluorescence of ChAT-positive fibres in the SCN was not sufficiently intense to permit clear identification of double labelling, with the protocol used in the present study (see below).

Two different antibodies to ChAT were used in the present study: a monoclonal antibody (Boehringer Mannheim, Montreal), and a polyclonal antibody raised in rabbit (Chemicon International, Temecula, CA).
The specificity of both antibodies has previously been documented (Eckenstein and Thoenen, '82; Bruce et al., '85).
It was also initially confirmed in a double immunofluorescence experiment that the two antibodies label identical cell populations.
In some cases where both antibodies were tried in conjunction with retrograde labelling, the pattern of labelling was the same.
However, background staining with the two antibodies varied to some extent depending on the tissue under investigation, as well as the protocol used.

Thus, for the best results, in the experiment which examined CUT-immunoreactive fibres, the monoclonal antibody was used preferentially, because the protocol used in this experiment, originally developed by Ojima et al. ('881, specifically required the use of this antibody for visualizing fibres.

In the retrograde labelling study, the polyclonal antibody was usually used to process brain sections because it appeared to provide slightly clearer staining with less background, especially for immunofluorescence.
For retinal sections, however, the monoclonal antibody was used preferentially because the use of this antibody in our protocol resulted in clearer staining with less background in retinal tissues.
It should be noted, however, that despite these slight differences, the two antibodies clearly identified the same populations of cholinergic neurons.
All control sections which were incubated with the omission of the primary antibodies showed no specific labelling.
Male Sprague Dawley rats weighing 200-250 g, obtained from Charles River Canada (St.
Constant, Quebec), were housed under a 12: 12 light-dark schedule, with free access to food and water.
ChAT-immunoreactive fibre localization in the SCN
The protocol for perfusion and immunohistochemistry was as described by Ojima et al. ('88).
This protocol was developed specifically for visualizing ChAT-immunoreactive fibres and terminals with the monoclonal antibody against ChAT from Boehringer-Mannheim.

Two rats were deeply anaesthetized by an intraperitoneal (i.p.1 injection of sodium pentobarbital (65 mgikg) and perfused for a few seconds with 0.1 M phosphate buffer (PB; pH 7.4) containing 0.002% calcium chloride followed by an ice cold fixative consisting of 4% paraformaldehyde and 0.2% glutaraldehyde in PB, for 3 minutes and then for a further 10 minutes by 4% paraformaldehyde alone; all perfusions were done at a rate of 10 mlimin.
The brain was immediately removed, blocked and postfixed in 4% paraformaldehyde at 4°C for 12 hours.
The brain was transferred to buffered 30% sucrose at 4°C overnight, rapidly frozen with dry ice and cut on a cryostat into 40 pm sections.
The sections were collected in 0.1 M Tris-buffered saline (TBS; pH 7.3), rinsed in three TBS washes of 20 minutes each and incubated in TBS containing 0.1% Triton X-100 for 20 minutes.

The sections were then treated with normal goat serum (1:30) in TBS for 1 hour at room temperature and incubated in a monoclonal antibody against ChAT (1:2.5; Boehringer-Mannheim) with 1:30 normal goat serum and 0.1% Triton X-100 at 37°C on a shaker for 2 days.
Subsequently, the sections were rinsed in TBS and incubated for 1 hour in goat anti-rat IgG (1:50) in TBS containing 1.8% bovine serum albumin, 1:30 normal goat serum and 0.1% Triton X-100.

The sections were then rinsed, incubated for 1 hour in rat peroxidase-antiperoxidase complex (1230) in TBS containing 1.8% bovine serum albumin, rinsed again and incubated in 0.06% diaminobenzidine in 0.1 M phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) for 10 minutes and labelling was subsequently visualized with 0.006% hydrogen peroxide.
The sections were mounted on gelatinized slides, airdried, dehydrated through an ascending alcohol series, coverslipped with Permount and viewed through an Olympus microscope.
Immunoreactive fibres in selected sections were drawn with the aid of a drawing tube attached to the microscope.
Retrograde tracing
Injection and perfusion.
Animals were anaesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (65 mg/kg, i.p.) and positioned in a Kopf stereotaxic holder with the incisor bar set 5 mm above the interaural line.

Unilateral injections of 8% fluorogold (in distilled water) were made into the SCN through a glass microelectrode (outside tip diameter of 25-35 km) positioned at 1.2 mm anterior to bregma and 0.2 mm lateral to the midline and lowered 9.8 mm ventral to the dura.
Fluorogold was delivered iontophoretically with a positive current of 2 FA administered over 10 minutes with a duty cycle of 5 seconds on and 5 seconds off.
At the end of the injection, the micropipette was kept in place for 5-10 minutes.
After one week survival in their normal lighting cycle, animals were deeply anaesthetized with sodium pentobarbital.
The descending aorta was clamped and the animal perfused intracardially with 60 ml of 0.9% saline followed by 400 ml of ice cold 4% paraformaldehyde made in 0.1 M PB (pH 7.4).
Brains were postfixed for 4-5 hours in the same fixative solution.
Coronal sections 50 Fm thick were cut from the forebrain and the brainstem on a microslicer.
After confirmation of injection sites, every sixth section was washed in 0.05 M TBS and then processed for immunohistochemistry for ChAT.
Eyeballs with the retina attached were removed after perfusion and cryoprotected in 30% sucrose for 24 hours.
Coronal sections 50 Frn thick were cut perpendicular to the anteroposterior axis of the eyeball on a cryostat and collected directly onto glass slides.
Sections were washed in TBS and processed for immunohistochemistry for CUT.
Immunocytochemistry.

Forebrain and brainstem sections were incubated for 48 hours at 4"C, in a polyclonal antibody raised in rabbit against ChAT (Chemicon), diluted to 1:lOO in antisera diluent (0.3% Triton X-100, 2.0% normal goat serum and 0.01% sodium azide added to 0.05 M TBS).

Subsequent to 3 x 20 minute rinses in TBS, the tissue was incubated in 1:20 dilution of Texas red conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG (Jackson Immunoresearch, West Grove, PA) in TBS and 1% normal goat serum.
Sections were mounted on slides, and dried overnight.

Retinal sections mounted on slides were processed with the monoclonal antibody to ChAT ( l : l O , Boehringer-Mannheim) and a Texas red-conjugated goat anti-rat IgG (Jackson Immunoresearch) as a secondary antibody.
All sections were coverslipped with either 1:9 concentration of ethylene diamine (Sigma) in glycerol or Fluoromount and examined with an Olympus epifluorescence microscope.
Fluorogold labelling was examined with an ultraviolet filter cube, and Texas red using a green filter cube.
All retrogradely labelled cells which were also labelled with ChAT were mapped by using standardized section drawings modified from Paxinos and Watson ('861, and selected examples were photographed.
Anterograde tracing
Biocytin was used as the anterograde tracer.
This tracer is transported rapidly and allows the placement of discrete injections as well as visualization of Golgi-like terminal morphology.
It was also originally claimed not to be taken up by fibres of passage (King et al., '89; Izzo, '91).
After the completion of the present study, however, a paper questioning this claim has been published (Chevalier et al., '92).
Rats were anaesthetized as described above and placed on a Kopf stereotaxic holder with the incisor bar 3.3 mm below the interaural line.

Injections of 50 nl of biocytin (5% in 0.05 M Tris buffer, pH 7.6) were made into the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus (PPT; coordinates: 7.3 mm posterior to bregma, 1.8 mm lateral to the midline and 5.5 mm ventral to the dura), the parabigeminal nucleus (PBg; coordinates: 7.7 mm posterior, 2.9 mm lateral and 6.5 mm ventral to surface of the skull) or the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (LDT; coordinates: 8.5 mm posterior, 0.9 mm lateral and 6.5 mm ventral to dura) through a glass micropipette (tip diameter 30 pm) attached to a 1 p1 Hamilton syringe.
The injections were made over a period of 10 minutes and the pipette was left in place for a further 5 minutes following the injection.

After survival periods ranging from 12 to 20 hours, the animals were given a lethal dose of pentobarbital and perfused transcardially with an initial rinse of 0.9% physiological saline followed by a mixture of 4% paraformaldehyde and 1% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
Brains were rapidly removed and postfixed overnight in 4% paraformaldehyde.
Coronal sections of the forebrain 50 pm thick containing the SCN region and the brainstem (to localize the injection site) were cut on a microslicer.
The sections were thoroughly washed in TBS (pH 7.4) and processed for histochemistry to visualize biocytin.
Histochemistry.
Free floating sections were incubated in 0.5% hydrogen peroxide for 30 minutes in order to decrease nonspecific labelling.

Sections were washed in TBS for 30 minutes and subsequently preincubated in 1% Triton X-100 in TBS for 60 minutes followed by incubation in Extravidin-peroxidase conjugate (Sigma) at a concentration of 1:20 for 2 hours.

The reaction product was visualized by preincubating the tissue in diaminobenzidine (0.5 mgiml) for 5 minutes followed by incubation in a mixture of diaminobenzidine and hydrogen peroxide (0.5 ml /ml of a 30% solution) for about 10 minutes or until the brown reaction product was visible.

Since dihydro nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) diaphorase activity has been shown to be a selective marker for cholinergic neurons in the PPT and LDT (Vincent et al., '831, this quick histochemical method was used to process the tissue further to determine whether the biocytin injection site in the brainstem overlapped with cholinergic neurons.
NADPH-diaphorase histochemistry.

Following biocytin histochemistry, the brainstem sections were processed for NADPH-diaphorase histochemistry (Scherer-Singler et al., '83) to examine the relationship between injection sites and cholinergic cell populations in the brainstem.
The sections were incubated in a mixture of P-NADPH (Sigma; 10 mg/10 ml) and nitroblue tetrazolium (Sigma; 1 mg/10 ml) in Tris buffer (pH 8.0) at 37°C for 5-10 minutes.
This reaction was performed in the dark, since nitroblue tetrazolium is light sensitive.
In cases where the injection site was acceptable, all sections were mounted on gelatinized slides, air dried, dehydrated in an ascending series of alcohols and coverslipped in Permount.
The sections were viewed through an Olympus microscope and in selected cases photographed.

Results.S: Scattered ChAT-immunoreactive fibres and terminals were found throughout the entire rostrocaudal extent of the SCN (Fig. 1).
Most of the fibre labelling was localized to the ventral aspects of the SCN, but a few fibres were also found in the dorsal SCN.
In addition, CUT-immunoreactive fibres were found in the optic chiasm ventral to the SCN as well as between the two SCN.
No CUT-immunoreactive fibres were observed in anterior hypothalamic and preoptic regions surrounding the SCN.
Figure 1B-D shows the location of ChAT-immunoreactive fibres at three levels (rostral, middle and caudal) of the SCN.
ChAT-immunoreactive neurons retrogradely labelled with fluorogold
Separate animals were used for the studies of the forebrain, brainstem, and the retina because these experiments were conducted at different times.

TTE.S: For the forebrain study, 3of the 12 rats had fluorogold injections localized in the SCN.
All three injection sites were mainly unilateral with some diffusion into the contralateral SCN as well as the optic chiasm.
An example of a fluorogold injection site is shown in Figure 2A; the retrogradely labelled cholinergic neurons in this case are mapped in Figures 3 and 4.
Figure 2 shows an example of a neuron located in the substantia innominata region of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex that was retrogradely labelled with fluorogold and immunopositive for ChAT.
ChAT-positive neurons that were retrogradely labelled from the SCN were typically large and multipolar.

These double-labelled neurons were observed bilaterally in the entire rostrocaudal extent of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex, but there were regional differences in the density of these double-labelled cells (Figs. 3 and 4).
The largest numbers of double-labelled neurons were located in the substantia innominata and nucleus basalis magnocellularis of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex (Fig. 4A-C).
Scattered double-labelled cells were localized in the medial septum as well as the vertical and horizontal limbs of the diagonal band of Broca (Figs. 3B-D, 4A).

The double-labelled neurons were intermingled with ChAT-positive neurons without the retrograde marker, as well as singly retrogradely labelled immunonegative neurons in these regions, and no obvious topography of doublelabelled neurons was seen within subregions of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex.

Within the cholinergic complex, single retrogradely labelled neurons without ChAT immunoreactivity occurred more frequently at rostral than caudal levels, and at caudal levels almost all retrogradely labelled neurons were ChAT-immunoreactive.

In addition to the cholinergic basal nuclear complex, consistent with previous reports (Pickard, '821, neurons that were not ChAT-immunoreactive but retrogradely labelled with fluorogold were found in the lateral septum (Fig. 3A,B), medial preoptic area (Figs. 3D,4A,B), contralatera1 SCN (Fig. 4C), zona incerta (Fig. 4D), and intergeniculate leaflet of the lateral geniculate nucleus.
Bminstem.
Two rats used in the brainstem study had their injection sites in the SCN, but with some diffusion to the contralateral SCN.
An example is shown in Figure 5; the diffusion into the contralateral side was greater in this case than the case shown in Figure 2A.
Neurons that were retrogradely labelled with fluorogold and were also ChAT-positive were seen in the PPT (Fig. 6A,D), LDT (Fig. 6B,E) and PBg (Fig. 6C,F).
Some neurons singly labelled with fluorogold were also present in these three nuclei.
No obvious topographic differences were seen between double and single retrogradely labelled neurons within the PPT, LDT or PBg.
Figure 7 illustrates the distribution of retrogradely labelled neurons in the brainstem.

In addition to double-labelled neurons, consistent with previous findings (Pickard, '821, retrogradely labelled immunonegative neurons were found occasionally in the dorsal and median raphe nuclei (Fig. 7B,C), superior colliculus (Fig. 7A,B), dorsal tegmental nucleus (Fig. 7E), and parabrachial nucleus (Fig. 7D-F).
No double-labelled neurons were observed in any of these nuclei.
Retina.
In the 3 rats used in the retina study, injection sites were unilateral but included the SCN as well as part of the optic chiasm ventral to it.
Most of the ChAT-immunoreactive cells in the retina were located in the inner nuclear layer, most likely corresponding to a subpopulation of amacrine cells.
Scattered cells in the ganglion cell layer were also immunopositive for CUT.
Many cells singly labelled with fluorogold were seen in the ganglion cell layer.
However, although there were a few ambiguous cases, there were no unequivocal cases of retinal cells that were retrogradely labelled with fluorogold and were also immunopositive for CUT.

Results.S: Biocytin injections directed at PPT, PBg, and LDT were made in two animals each.
Figure 8A-C shows examples of biocytin injections placed in PPT, PBg, and LDT, respectively.
The location of the injection sites overlapped with NADPH-diaphorase positive (thus cholinergic; Vincent et al., '83) neurons in the PPT and LDT (not shown).
Cholinergic PBg neurons are not NADPH-diaphorase positive; therefore, anatomical landmarks were used to determine the location of the injection site.

TTE.S: Scattered anterogradely labelled fibres and terminals were detected in the SCN after biocytin injections into PPT, (Fig. 8A, D), LDT (Fig. 8B, E), and PBg (Fig. 8C, F).
In each case, these fibres were found throughout the entire rostrocaudal extent of the SCN, and their density was usually greater than that seen with CUT-immunoreactive fibres (Fig. 1).
Following injections into PBg and PPT, fine fibres could be seen entering the SCN through the optic chiasm (Fig. 8E,F).

In the case of PPT injections, thicker fibres could also be seen coursing through the optic chiasm at the level of the caudal SCN, and a few scattered fibres were also observed in the lateral hypothalamus.
Extensive fibre labelling was also observed in the basal forebrain area following both PPT and LDT injections.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
ChAT-immunoreactive fibres were detected in the SCN, suggesting the existence of cholinergic input into the SCN.
Cholinergic fibers appeared to enter the SCN from the ventral aspect via the optic chiasm.
These results are consistent with txevious findings (van den Pol and Tsujimoto, 85; Ichikawa and Hiratay 86).
Ichikawa and Hirata ( 86) Observed very dense C hAT-positive fibres in the ventromedial aspect of the rat SCN with fine mesh-like CUT-positive fibres distributed elsewhere within the SCN.
In the present study, although we observed many fibres in the ventromedial aspects of the SCN, we did not find the dense labelling observed by Ichikawa and Hirata ('86).
This disparity in the findings may be due to the different sources of antibodies as well as different immunohistochemical techniques used in the two studies.
Neurons retrogradely labelled from the SCN were found in both the basal forebrain and the brainstem.

In the basal forebrain, cells labelled with fluorogold and immunopositive for C U T were found in the entire rostrocaudal extent of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex with highest densities occurring in the caudal nuclei, including the nucleus basalis magnocellularis and substantia innominata.
Noncholinergic retrogradely labelled cells were observed in the lateral septum, lateral geniculate nucleus, and zona incerta.

Although no cholinergic cells were found in the lateral septum in the present study, a small cluster of weakly CUT-immunoreactive neurons has been localized in the lateral septum (Kimura et al., '91).
Retrogradely labelled neurons projecting to the SCN have been reported in hamsters using free horseradish peroxidase as a retrograde tracer (Pickard, '82).
That study reported retrogradely labelled neurons in lateral septum, medial septum, and the vertical limb of the diagonal band of Broca.
No labelled cells were found in the horizontal limb of the diagonal band of Broca, magnocellular preoptic area, or any of the caudal nuclei of the cholinergic basal nuclear complex.
In the present study, however, many retrogradely labelled cells were found not only in the medial septum but also throughout the cholinergic basal nuclear complex.
The differences between the results of these two studies may be due to the type of tracer used.

Fluorogold has been shown to be superior to horseradish peroxidase as a retrograde tracer, and its sensitivity is reportedly comparable to that of wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (Schmued and Fallon, '86).

It has also been reported that fluorogold is not taken up by undamaged fibres of passage, and that there is little or no transsynaptic labelling, since long survival times do not appear to result in increased cell labelling (Schmued and Fallon, '86).
Another possible explanation for the disparity between the two studies is species differences, since the study by Pickard ('82) was done using Syrian hamsters rather than rats.

Although not identified in the present study, the presence of short cholinergic projections to the SCN arising in an anterior hypothalamic region lateral to the SCN has previously been reported in two abstracts.

Fuller et al. ('89) used AChE histochemistry as a marker for cholinergic cells and horseradish peroxidase as a retrograde tracer, and reported double-labelled cells in the diagonal band and an area lateral to and beyond the boundary of the SCN (referred to as 'LASCN,' not to be confused with the lateral SCN) in the rat.

Although AChE is not a selective marker for cholinergic neurons (Satoh et al., '831, a similar result was found by Dwyer et al. ('90) in the hamster, by using immunohistochemistry with a polyclonal antibody to ChAT and rhodamine-conjugated latex microspheres as the retrograde tracer.

The presence of cholinergic neurons in the regions surrounding the SCN is controversial, because although these regions appear to contain ChAT-immunoreactive neurons (Tago et al., '871, no neurons containing mRNA for ChAT are present (Oh et al., '92).
In the present study, no ChAT-labelled neurons were found in the area lateral to the SCN.
This difference between our results and those of Fuller et al. ('89) and Dwyer et al. ('90) may be attributable to species differences or differences in the sensitivity of the antibodies used.
On the other hand, while neurons bearing cholinergic markers may exist lateral to the SCN, we found no evidence of retrograde labelling in this region.
Since our fluorogold tracing identified other projections to the SCN that had been described previously, the sensitivity of the retrograde tracer does not appear to be a problem.
On the basis of these data, therefore, it seems unlikely to us that the rat SCN receives a projection from neurons in this region lateral to the SCN.
In the brainstem, retrogradely labelled cholinergic neurons were localized in three distinct nuclei, namely the PPT, PBg and LDT.
As previously reported (Tago et al., '89), the PPT and LDT contain strongly ChAT-positive neurons, whereas neurons in the PBg are only weakly ChAT-immunoreactive.
A recent study using in situ hybridization has reported high levels of mRNA for ChAT in the PPT and LDT, but very low levels in the PBg (Oh et al., '92).

Previous studies do not report fibre labelling in the SCN following injections of the anterograde tracers wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase or Phaseolus uulgaris-leucoagglutinin into the LDT (Satoh and Fibiger, '86; Cornwall et al., 'go), whereas following the injection of Phaseolus uulgaris-leucoagglutinin into the PPT, although not noted by the authors, labelled fibres appear to be present in the SCN (Hallanger and Wainer, '88; their Fig. 3D).

Consistent with the latter observation, retrogradely labelled neurons have been observed in the PPT region following horseradish peroxidase injections into the retrochiasmatic area and caudal part of the SCN (Zaborszky et al., '84).

The present retrograde labelling data also suggest that in addition to cholinergic projections from the PPT and LDT regions, there are also projections arising from noncholinergic neurons that are mixed with cholinergic neurons in the same regions.
This provides one explanation for the fact that the density of fibres anterogradely labelled with biocytin from the PPT, LDT, or PBg was greater than that of ChAT-immunoreactive fibres in the SCN.
An alternate but not mutually exclusive explanation is that the immunohistochemical procedures used in the present study were not sensitive enough to reveal all cholinergic fibres in the SCN.
At present, the neurotransmitter content of these noncholinergic projections from the PPT, LDT, and PBg regions is not known.

Retrogradely labelled neurons in the PBg have been visualized in the cat following horseradish peroxidase injections into the optic chiasm with diffusion of the tracer into the SCN (Baleydier and Magnin, '79).

The PBg is known to innervate the contralateral superior colliculus (Mufson et al., '86) through a long loop which ascends along the optic tract, crosses the midline in Gudden's supraoptic commissure, and returns along the contralateral optic tract (Graybiel, '78).
It is most likely that some of these fibres reach the SCN at the most rostra1 level of this loop.
It is, however, also possible that the labelling in the PBg in the present study is, in part, due to leakage of the tracer into the optic tract and its uptake by potential damaged fibres.
This possibility is suggested by the observation of a few retrogradely labelled cells in the superior colliculus.

Since the superior colliculus projects to the lateral posterior nucleus of the thalamus through the supraoptic commissure, the observation of retrogradely labelled cells in the superior colliculus suggests that there was some leakage of the tracer into the supraoptic commissure.
Therefore some of the PBg neurons labelled by fluorogold may be the neurons projecting to the superior colliculus via the optic tracts.
Anterogradely labelled fibres were observed in the SCN following biocytin injections into PPT, PBg and LDT.

In view of a recent report of the uptake of this tracer by passing fibres (Chevalier et al., '921, the possibility exists that these labelled fibers in the SCN actually represented fibres which passed through these brainstem regions but arose from neurons whose cell bodies were located further caudally.
This is particularly a concern for injections in the PPT, which is located amongst various fibre tracts.

Despite this caveat, however, these anterograde labelling results confirm that the retrogradely labelled neurons observed in these brainstem nuclei following fluorogold injections into the SCN were not entirely due to the tracer being taken up by damaged fibres of passage.
With all three injections, thin biocytin labelled fibres and terminals were observed in the entire rostrocaudal extent of the SCN with the highest density being found in the ventral SCN.

Observation of labelled fibres in the basal forebrain area in the cases of PPT and LDT injections and in the lateral hypothalamus in the case of PPT injections are consistent with previous findings (Satoh and Fibiger, '86; Hallanger and Wainer, '88; Cornwall et al., '90).

Although it was not technically feasible to confirm the cholinergic nature of fibres anterogradely labelled from the brainstem, the presence of ChATimmunoreactive fibres in the SCN combined with the retrograde and anterograde tracing data provide strong support for the presence of cholinergic projections from the basal forebrain and mesopontine tegmentum to the SCN.
The absence of clearly double-labelled cells in the retina indicates that few, if any, retinal ganglion cells projecting to the SCN are cholinergic.

This conclusion does not imply that cholinergic effects on rhythms cannot be mediated in part via the retina, since noncholinergic ganglion cells projecting to the SCN could readily be influenced by connections from retinal cholinergic neurons.
Cholinergic neurons in the cholinergic basal nuclear complex and in the mesopontine tegmentum have been implicated in the regulation of sleep and arousal (Steriade and McCarley, '90; Semba, '91).
In addition, carbachol has been shown to produce phase shifts in circadian rhythms in rodents.
These findings and the present results taken together suggest that ACh released from the cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain and brainstem influence the resetting of the circadian clock.
The basal forebrain area containing cholinergic neurons has been shown to receive retinal terminals in both hamsters and rats (Youngstrom et al., '91; Bina, '92).
Thus, it is possible that photic input reaching the cholinergic basal nuclear complex activates these cholinergic cells, resulting in the release of ACh in the SCN.

This ACh could then act either directly on pacemaker cells, or indirectly through interneurons that make synaptic connections with pacemaker cells, to alter clock mechanisms, thereby contributing to a phase shift of circadian rhythms.

The new phase of the clock would be transmitted to the forebrain, brainstem and thalamic nuclei involved in the generation and maintenance of sleep and arousal and to autonomic nuclei, presumably via polysynaptic pathways from the SCN.
This model proposes a feedback loop in which neural mechanisms involved in the regulation of sleep and wakefulness are linked to the area responsible for circadian timing of these processes.
One missing link to this hypothesis is that it is not known whether the retinal fibres entering the basal forebrain terminate on cholinergic neurons.

In addition, there are no direct efferent projections from the SCN to the cholinergic basal nuclear complex, to the aminergic (the dorsal raphe and the locus coeruleus) and cholinergic brainstem nuclei involved in sleep and arousal, or to any of the autonomic nuclei.
Indirect and amplified connections to these nuclei made via the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, the major target of SCN efferents, do however, remain a possibility (Watts et al., '87).

These studies and previously published results provide strong evidence to suggest that cholinergic cells located in several distinct cholinergic nuclei in the basal forebrain and in the PPT, LDT and PBg of the brainstem project to and terminate throughout the SCN.
There are populations of both M1 and M2 muscarinic receptors in the SCN on which ACh released from these terminals may act (Bina et al., '90b).
The cellular components on which these receptors are localized have yet to be identified.
